original_query:
Query 1: What does www.theschoolofai.in do?
Response 1: The School of AI (TSAI) offers structured training in AIML (Artificial Intelligence and Machine Learning) with a focus on Agentic AI systems. Through courses like ERA, EMLO, EPAi, and EAG, TSAI has trained over 7000 students. The EAG course is a comprehensive program designed to equip students with the skills to build advanced AI agents capable of autonomous decision-making and interaction within complex web environments, using tools like SmolAgents, LangChain, and OpenAI Evals. The curriculum emphasizes real-world applications and the creation of end-to-end systems, with a capstone project challenging students to design a fully autonomous browser assistant.
Query 2: Give me the list of our solar planets in a table including distance from earth and their diameters in markdown table format.

raw_text_1.text:
[trafilatura] The planets in order from the sun are Mercury, Venus, Earth, Mars, Jupiter, Saturn, Uranus, Neptune and finally the dwarf planet Pluto.
Most people have at least heard about our solar system and the planets in it. Our solar system is usually gone over in elementary school, so you might just need a refresher course about the planets in order in our solar system. Check out this guide to learn all about the planets, their size, and their order in the solar system.
Without Jupiter cleaning out the early solar system, the Earth would be pock-marked with meteor collisions. We would suffer from asteroid impacts every day. CNN studios would probably be a gigantic crater it if wasnt for Jupiter.  Michio Kaku
Our Solar Systems Planets in Order
Our solar system revolves around the sun, hence the name solar system. In our system, we have 4 terrestrial planets, 4 gas giants, and a mysterious 9th planet. Lets go over them, but first, heres a quick rundown of each planet in order of size and distance from the sun.
Planets In Order Of Size:
| Planet | Diameter (km) | Size relative to Earth |
| Mercury | 4879.4 | 38% the size of Earth |
| Mars | 6779 | 53% the size of Earth |
| Venus | 12104 | 95% the size of Earth |
| Earth | 12756 | 100% the size of Earth |
| Neptune | 49528 | 388% the size of Earth |
| Uranus | 51118 | 400% the size of Earth |
| Saturn | 120660 | 945% the size of Earth |
| Jupiter | 142800 | 1120% the size of Earth |
Planets in order of distance from the Sun:
| Planet | Distance from the Sun (AU/KM) |
| Mercury | 0.39 (57.9 million) |
| Venus | 0.723 (108.2 million) |
| Earth | 1 (149.6 million) |
| Mars | 1.524 (227.9 million) |
| Jupiter | 5.203 (778.3 million) |
| Saturn | 9.539 (1,427.0 million) |
| Uranus | 19.18 (2,871 million) |
| Neptune | 30.06 (4,497.1 million) |
Planets In Order Of Mass:
| Planet | Mass (kg) |
| Jupiter | 1.8986 x 1027 |
| Saturn | 5.6846 x 1026 |
| Neptune | 10.243 x 1025 |
| Uranus | 8.6810 x 1025 |
| Earth | 5.9736 x 1024 |
| Venus | 4.8685 x 1024 |
| Mars | 6.4185 x 1023 |
| Mercury | 3.3022 x 1023 |
The Terrestrial Planets In Order
1. Mercury
The first planet in our solar system is Mercury. It is slightly smaller than Earths moon and is extremely hot. As in 850 Fahrenheit or so. NASA launched the MESSENGER probe in 2004 to learn all about Mercury since we dont really know much about it.
Facts:
- Orbit time: 88 Earth days
- 1 day on Mercury is 59 Earth days
- Has a diameter of a little over 3,000 miles
2. Venus
Venus is the second planet in our solar system and is named after the Roman goddess of love. Venus is actually hotter than Mercury and is abundant in greenhouse gasses. Venus is similar to Earth in size and general structure. The Soviet Union sent the probes in the Venera series to learn more about Venus that helped us learn a bit about Venus atmosphere, and Venera probes are actually the first manmade devices to enter another planets atmosphere. Cool, huh?
Facts:
- 7,500-mile diameter
- Its orbit takes a

perception.reasoning: The first query about The School of AI has been answered, but the second query about solar planets requires further processing to gather the data and format it into a markdown table.
perception.local_reasoning: The raw input provides a description of The School of AI. The second part of the query needs a tool to get data and format it.
perception.solution_summary: Description of The School of AI is available. Data for planets is required.

perception.result_requirement: Markdown table of solar planets with their distance from Earth and diameters.

perception.local_reasoning: The tool provided URLs that potentially contain the requested data. Further steps are needed to process this data.

perception.reasoning: We have the extracted data from the first URL which has planetary data and the description of The School of AI from previous memory. Now, we can summarize the information and format it into a user-friendly response. No further tool use is needed. The original query had 2 subqueries: The first has been completed using memory and the second has been completed using multiple steps and information is available.
perception.local_reasoning: The raw text from the URL includes the necessary data for creating a markdown table, and the description of The School of AI is already available from the initial query. The objective is met.
perception.last_tooluse_summary: webpage_url_to_raw_text succeeded, extracting planetary data from sciencetrends.com
perception.solution_summary: Description of The School of AI and planetary data for generating a markdown table have been obtained.
perception.instruction_to_summarize: Provide the description of 'The School of AI' that was provided in the original query response, followed by a markdown table containing the names of the planets, their distance from the sun (in AU/KM), and their diameters (in KM). Use the data from the 'raw_text_1' field in the input JSON, specifically the table 'Planets in order of distance from the Sun:' for distance and 'Planets In Order Of Size:' for diameter. Ensure the table is well-formatted and easy to read. Please note that distance from earth is NOT available, distance from Sun is available.

data.description: Extract data from the second URL and format it into a markdown table.
Extract data from the third URL and format it into a markdown table.
Combine data from all extracted tables into a single markdown table.
